2818.92.text:
or four key elements,
it won't work.

2821.35.text:
So, it's not like you can
go out and just say, "Hey,

2823.58.text:
I want one of those index
universal life policies

2826.36.text:
and expect it to work
this way, right?"

2828.54.text:
it has to have certain
things as associated with it

2834.03.text: So, the question is who monitors

2836.21.text:
or who manages the
execution of the plan, right?

2840.01.text: And the answer is both, right?

2842.38.text:
The client and the agent who
helped you do it are going

2845.64.text: to have to do both, right?

2850.16.text:
You're going to have to --
unfortunately, it's more manual.

2853.23.text:
The question is it
similar to buying bonds?

2861.75.text:
In the sense that
it's a secure --

2864.00.text:
it's more of a secure type of a
savings fund, but bonds operate

2867.60.text:
on a whole different type of a,
yeah, it's a different scale.

2871.43.text:
She's using the phrase federal
loan versus home loan, right?

2875.09.text:
And when you say federal loan,
are you talking about, like,

2877.55.text:
the loan from the
insurance company?

2879.57.text:
Yeah. The insurance company
has nothing to do with credits.

2884.14.text:
It's just -- the insurance
company is just saying --

2887.14.text:
so, banks, the reason
why they --

2888.61.text: you take a loan from the bank --

2890.36.text:
the reason why you have a
payment, like the next month is

2893.57.text:
because they're giving
you borrowed money, right?

2896.41.text:
They're giving you borrow --
so they need your money back

2898.64.text:
to be able to do what they
need to do with it, right?

2907.80.text:
They're not going to give you
more than what you already have.

2910.30.text:
So, if you had 30,000
in your account,

2912.44.text:
they're not going
to give you 100,000.

2914.18.text:
They will only give you
up to, say, that 30,000.

2917.04.text:
Or, like I showed here,
whatever is spendable.

2921.75.text:
which could be less than what's
actually in your account.

2924.78.text:
So, as a result, they're
never going backwards.

2927.73.text:
And that's why they're
willing to be patient

2930.01.text:
because they know two things
are guaranteed to happen

2933.22.text:
and they're going to
get their money back.

2935.15.text:
One, you're going
to cancel the plan

2938.40.text:
and whatever loans you've taken,
they take their money back

2941.16.text:
and give you the
difference and you walk away.

2943.58.text: Or you're going to pass away.

2945.45.text:
And in that sense, they're
going to take their money back

2947.83.text:
with interest and give
you the difference and pay

2955.05.text:
So, these loans don't
show up on credit.

2959.11.text:
It's not something that you
report on any tax forms.

2964.87.text:
where you're utilizing your
money that's already there to,

2970.87.text:
You know, because if you want
to pay off a student load --

2974.84.text:
like in the example -- you
either drain your account

2977.83.text:
and pay it off and that money
is gone, never to be used again

2980.25.text: or to give you any benefit.

2981.66.text:
Or you loan against
it, pay the loan off

2984.45.text:
and have the money
still grow for you.

2987.06.text: So, you get the double dip.

2988.66.text:
You get to pay the loan off
and still have your money

2990.56.text:
to give you interest for
the rest of your life.

2994.08.text:
Yes, so the question
is what kind of --

2996.09.text:
does the interest rate variable
or fixed, kind of a thing,

2999.56.text: on the loans that you take?

3001.14.text:
And it really --
you can do either.

3003.05.text:
And it really depends on the
company that you're using --

3006.31.text:
whoever is -- the policy
you're utilizing that has --

3009.68.text:
the way that they do their
loans type of a thing.

3013.42.text:
But it can be fixed, it can
be variable, you know, with --

3017.69.text:
a lot of times, with the
variable ones, there is a cap

3021.12.text:
on what the interest rate could
go up to, so it protects you

3023.84.text: as well, type of a thing.
